James Hunt.Action: Flirts with several hot-looking girls, surrounded by girlfriends and hangers-on, projecting a rock star image.
Decides to stay on wet tyres while others switch to slicks in changing conditions.
Surrounded by TV crews, girlfriends, and hangers-on, prioritizing glamour and magnetism despite his smaller team size.
Roars out of the pits ahead with new tyres on, maintaining a strong position (3rd place).
Appears to have caused or been part of a problematic tyre change leading to delay for Niki, the mechanic's frustration indicating possible miscommunication or hurried action.
Arrives at the hospital after a race accident, calmly confirming that the racetrack telephoned ahead to prepare for his arrival.
Downplays his injuries and remains confident, showing no panic despite visible bruising and a black eye.
Refuses to share details about his on-track disagreement when questioned by the nurse.
Shows some openness by admitting the extent of his injury and engages frankly with the nurse.
Responds evasively and with a sharp tone when asked about the source of his injury ('None of your business. Ouch.').
Invites the nurse to see his injuries closely, making eye contact and showing a form of sincere engagement.
Engages in a passionate, physically intense encounter with the nurse, suggesting a strong, intimate connection, which may indicate warmth and sincere human connection in personal relations.
Reflects philosophically and vulnerably on his allure to women and life, showing emotional honesty.
Dismisses nurse's questions evasively, shows bravado in interactions, focuses on physical relationships rather than situation at hand.
Demonstrates self-awareness about the appeal of racing drivers linked to their risk-taking and proximity to death.
Leads the nurse around the race track and introduces her to his team with casual friendliness.
Refers to the nurse by a nickname ('Nursie') without noticing her correction.
Explains clearly and confidently the structure of racing divisions and his own position in them to the nurse.
Demonstrates willingness to take personal risks and push limits to gain advantage in racing.
Associates recklessness with competence, showing a potentially risky mindset.
Introduces Nursie warmly to others, calling her 'anything BUT a bore'.
Makes an unpleasant vomiting sound in front of others.
Strips off and prepares confidently for the race, reassuring others about Nursie.
Vomits due to nerves or stress before the race.

Admits openly his flaws, including hot-headedness, intolerance, and quickness to fight.
States he has difficulties with people and falls out with them frequently.
Claims the only creatures he has cared for and treated well are budgerigars.

Acknowledges publicly that he is a liability in normal life but quick in a car.
Admits to having a hot head, inability to tolerate discipline, and settling matters with fists.

Attracts a crowd of pretty women at the celebration, seeming friendly and sociable.
Makes chicken noises repeatedly after mention of Goosestepper's insult to amateurs.
Expresses envy but also admiration for a bold financial decision ('That's either an act of utter lunacy, or the ballsiest thing I ever heard.')
Expresses envy but recognizes that taking a big financial risk might be ballsy and impressive.
Is described by Reggazoni as a driver known for excessive partying and sexual exploits, implying a wild, self-centered lifestyle.
Reputation as an OK driver but also as a reckless 'suicidal jerk' on track.
Known among peers for intense stamina and charm off the track (implied by being an 'IMMORTAL fuck').
Immediately recognizes that the March 731 car is an F1 car rather than Formula 2, demonstrating technical knowledge and awareness.
Questions Hesketh's decision to race in F1 instead of Formula 2, showing critical thinking and understanding of the racing hierarchy.
Embraces Hesketh in excitement upon learning about the F1 project without hesitation, showing confidence and positive engagement.

Suggests canceling the race out of respect for the deceased driver.

Rolls his eyes when advised to spend more time with mechanics and less in bars and nightclubs.
Responds sarcastically to suggestions about professionalism and maturity, showing resistance to constructive criticism.
